subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I already looked it up, and it agreed with what I said: Phonemes are not the physical segments themselves, but abstractions of them. An example of a
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tinyallen" <Tinyallen@...> wrote:
>
> There really is no room for misunderstanding here.
>
> The term 'phoneme' is a technical one, having a precise meaning.
>
> If you use the established term, you must accept the established
> meaning. If you wish to mean something else, then either use another
> word (possibly created) or deal with the confusion you have caused.
>
> Check out: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme
>

I already looked it up, and it agreed with what I said:

Phonemes are not the physical segments themselves, but abstractions of
them. An example of a phoneme would be the /t/ found in words like
tip, stand, writer, and cat.

So that seems to agree with what you and John say.

But an abstraction has concrete elements. That is, you can point to
physical characteristics that make up the phoneme, even though it may
be an abstraction. Sure enough, later in the wikipedia, I read:

Two sounds that may be allophones (sound variants belonging to the
same phoneme) in one language may belong to separate phonemes in
another language or dialect.

This is exactly as I said. The Irish have a sound I cannot
distinguish--an allophone. But amongst themselves they can understand
it as having a whole different meaning--hence it is a phoneme for
them, exactly as I argued, exactly as I learned it in linguistics.

respectfully

Paul
